item.caption: Instructions

item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
A copy of these instructions will be made available to your primary care doctor or nurse practitioner: JOEL K LYM MD
You were treated in the hospital for alcohol withdrawal.
You can call the appointment / advice line at 1-866-454-8855, if you experience any of the following symptoms:
Temperature of 100.4 degrees F or above.
Pain unrelieved by medication.
Persistent nausea, vomiting and/or inability to eat.
Increase in fatigue, confusion or dizziness.
Diarrhea that is bloody or occurs more than 5-6 times a day or persists for more than 3-4 days.
You can also send your doctor a non-urgent message at www.kp.org under My Message Center. Response may take up to 2 business days.
Call 911 for emergencies.
FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS
You have a Telephone Appointment with your regular doctor, JOEL K LYM MD, in 2 DAYS. You will need to be available by phone for 30 minutes before and after your appointment time for my provider to be able to reach you. Your provider and I will determine at the time of the telephone appointment if any further medication changes, tests, or other appointments will be needed. Please keep any other appointments you have with your specialists.
Telephone and Video Visit Appointments (DONE REMOTELY in your place)
Appointment Date & Time Visit Type Provider Department
Sep 23, 2020 2:40 PM PDT VIDEO APPOINTMENT VISIT Lym, Joel K (M.D.) MD1B
Call the appointment / advice line at 1-866-454-8855 if you need to change an appointment.
REFERRALS
The following referrals have been made for you:
Chemical Dependency Recovery Program (CDRP)
TOPICS TO DISCUSS WITH MY DOCTOR
Discuss the following with your primary care doctor or treating surgeon:
Need help with alcohol cessation?
DIET
Regular Diet: Consume a diet high in fiber such as whole grains, fruits, vegetables, protein from chicken, fish, and vegetable sources to stay healthy. Avoid eating red meats, fats (butter or cream), sugary drinks, and desserts.
ACTIVITIES AND LIFESTYLE
You can do the following: You may do whatever is comfortable for you.
Absolutely no alcohol.

Chief Complaint:
Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
NAUSEA AND VOMITING
on a 30 day injection course for Alcohol withdrawl, mid way thru the 30 day at this time. also taking phenobarb but vomited. diaphoretic and constant vomiting x 2 hrs
Reason for readmission: EtOh withdrawal.
This history was obtained from the patient or review of the chart.
HPI
Manav Agarwal is a 34 Y male patient with a past medical history of EtOH use, anxiety who is presenting with nausea vomiting in setting of alcohol withdrawal.
Patient was recently admitted on 8/28 to 8/30 for Alcohol withdrawal treated, had hallucination and started on vpa withdrawal protocol, later discharged home after improvement. On discharge patient's naltrexone was discontinued.
In the ED: Vitals w/ HR upto 125, BP stable. Resp upto 20. SpO2 100. K of 3.4, Mg of 1.6. LFT's normal. EtOh level <0.01. Patient given phenobarbital, ativan, haldol in the ED. HBS consulted for further management.
Upon interview patient reports that he started having bouts of nausea and vomiting, tried taking phenobarb at home, however, threw up. Came to ED. Reports drinking a bottle of wine evening of 9.18. Reports he wants to quit but needs help. Denies any other symptoms. No fevers, chills or sob. Reports he stopped taking phenobarb because it made him sleepy.

item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Date and Time of initial evaluation:9/21/2020 11:34 AM
ADDICTION MEDICINE CONSULTATION LIAISON INITIAL CONSULTATION
Reason for consult: Consult was requested by HBS for evaluation and MEDICAL treatment of alcohol withdrawal
Patient's rights, use of automated medical record, Primary Care Provider and Behavioral Health Services Provider access to medical record, consent to treatment, and confidentiality as well as exceptions to confidentiality including SI, HI, child abuse and elder abuse, were reviewed. yes
CHIEF COMPLAINT nausea and vomiting
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Manav Agarwal is a 34 Y male with a history of alcohol use disorder presented in alcohol withdrawal 2 days ago and was treated with gabapentin and clonidine and as needed ativan and has improved and is now eating and walking. Patient says drinks 3-6 bottles of wine per week with at most 2 bottles per day. Patient says alcohol has been a little to much for a long time but for the last year clearly a problem. Patient desires to stop for a period of time and definitely cut down forever. Patient studies data in school and lives with family. Patient has gotten naltrexone im a few weeks ago and has oral to take. Patient not covered as outpatient for addiction services in Kaiser and has not gone to AA. Patient and family looking into getting kasier coverage for addiction services and getting into program independently.
IMPRESSION:
Alcohol withdrawal - improved would discharge on gabapentin 300 tid for 4 days.
Alcohol use disorder - oral naltexone 500 mg po qday. Patient to be followed by phone and helped to transition to AA meetings as well as county resources through highland bridge clinic.at 510-545-2765, as well as family. Patient denies drugs, thc, or cigarettes.

Kaiser Fremont Initial Psychosocial Assessment
Social Work Plan:
Follow up: No further follow up needs at this time.

Long Term Plan: Patient expects to return to prior level of function.
Patient is committed to living independently.
POLST not on file.

Health Care Agents
Pratima Agarwal Designated Decision Maker - Mother Not Active
Primary Phone: 510-673-0499 (Mobile)
Home Phone: 510-673-0499
Work Phone: 510-673-0499
Vijay Agarwal Designated Decision Maker - Parent Active
Primary Phone: 510-914-6278 (Mobile)
Home Phone: 510-914-6278
Work Phone: 510-914-6278
Assessment/Summary:
MSW visited pts room x2, unable to speak due to patient being busy.
MSW called pts room after a few hours, able to speak with him. Pt is alert and oriented with h/o alcohol abuse. Pt was seen SW during his previous admission on 8/30/2020. Pt was referred to CDRP. MSW discussed his coping skills have been at this time and also follow up with CDRP. Pt reports that he cannot attend CDRP due to his insurance issues. Pt has Medi-cal and not a kaiser benefit for follow up with CDRP. MSW suggested that pt follow up with ACCESS Mental health. MSW also suggested Alcohol anonymous meetings. Pt acknowledged of working with AA virtually. Pt is also working on becoming kaiser member so that he can access chemical dependency resources. Pt appreciative of the visit / phone call as well. Pt also reports that his family is supportive and that he is still struggling with his school and covid at this time.
Non-Member/Uninsured Brief Intervention & Counseling:
Conducted a brief intervention and counseling with patient: expressed concern for drinking beyond low risk limits, linked to their overall health and recommended patient decrease intake or quit. Discussed the risk of drinking beyond the low risk limits and explored patient readiness to cut back or quit. Discussed with patient how different amounts of drinking might affect their current medications and overall health. Discussed areas where patient's drinking has negatively impacted patient's life and the lives of friends, family, others. Reviewed and discussed when patient has continued to drink despite negative consequences of drinking. Collaboratively discussed reasons for decreasing or eliminating drinking alcohol. Provided patient education. Asked the patient if he/she would like to set a goal to follow-up with their primary care physician and (county or private chemical dependency programs) after they are discharged from the acute care setting. A list of community resources including chemical dependency treatment programs and community support groups were given to patient. We also assisted patient with making contact with ACCESS Mental Health program to find out about admission process.
